MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Fish Catch in Territorial Waters.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Wallace Mr. D. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the total value of the fish catch in Irish territorial waters in each of the last five years; the percentage of this catch taken by Irish fishermen; and if comparable statistics are available for other EC countries with significant territorial waters such as France, Spain, the UK and Greece.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: Details of Ireland's fish catch are recorded by ICES (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea) statistical area. ICES areas are used by the European Community to assign fishing quotas to member states. These areas do not correspond with Irish or, indeed, any member state's territorial waters. Accordingly, the information sought by the Deputy is not available.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Waterford Shellfish Development.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if Dungarvan Bay in County Waterford has been designated for the purpose of shellfish development; if he will name the individuals, or companies who have been given foreshore licences for oyster farming in this bay; and the procedures, if any, that were followed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: Dungarvan Harbour has not been designated for aquaculture under the Fisheries Act, 1980. A number of individual applications for licensing of shellfish operations at specific sites in the Harbour are being considered under the Fisheries (Consolidation) Act, 1959 and the Foreshore Act, 1933.

MainHeading.P: Applications are being assessed by the Department from the relevant technical and scientific perspectives. A public consultative process (which includes advertisement of proposals in the local press) is underway, involving the local authority and local community interests as well as other relevant bodies including the Wildlife Service, with a view to securing the agreement of all concerned to the allocation of sites as between the various applicants.

To date, three licences have been granted to three shellfish operators in Dungarvan Harbour. The licensees are as follows: Waterford Shellfish Ltd in respect of oyster and clam cultivation; Iasc Sliogach Dungarbhan in respect of oyster cultivation; and PKA Ltd in respect of oyster and clam cultivation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Waterford Harbour.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to visit Helvick harbour in County Waterford to witness the difficult conditions under which local fishermen have to work due to the lack of development of the harbour; and if he will provide finance for the improvement sought by the fishermen in an application submitted six years ago.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: Since my appointment as Minister for the Marine I have visited a number of harbours, both fishing and commercial, around the coast. While I have no immediate plan to visit Helvick Harbour, I hope in due course to see the facility at first hand.

MainHeading.P: Helvick Harbour is the responsibility of Waterford County Council. The Department of the Marine is providing grant-aid to the County Council in respect of remedial works undertaken at the harbour during 1992. There are no plans to undertake any development works at Helvick Harbour during 1993. However, the Department of the Marine is drawing up a Fishery Harbour Development Programme for the period 1994 to 1997 and the development of Helvick Harbour will be considered in the context of this programme. Pending finalisation of the programme and clarification of its funding, I am not in a position to say what development works, if any, can be undertaken at Helvick Harbour.

Qst.Quest: if there will be a public hearing held before any decision is made in relation to the proposed expansion of shellfishing at Bannow Bay, County Wexford in view of the differing opinions and the controversy in the locality concerning this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: In addition to the detailed technical assessment of all aspects of aquaculture proposals, there is a public consultative process inherent in the licensing system operated by the Department. There is an established system of consultation with the relevant statutory bodies as well as the system of public notice under which all comments and objections received are considered and taken into account.

If I conclude that a public hearing would elicit critical information which would not otherwise be forthcoming then I will not rule the option out. I am not, however, contemplating such a hearing at this time.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the facts that major structural damage has been caused to Cloonagh Pier, Maugherow, County Sligo by the storms in January 1993, that there is a danger of the pier disintegrating unless repair and reconstruction work is carried out, that severe damage will be done to the livelihoods of local fishermen if the pier were unusable; and if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that the Cloonagh Pier is of major historical interest because of its former use by the Inismurray Islanders and also because of its association with the poems of Eva Gore-Booth; and if in view of all these considerations, he will ensure that immediate action is taken to start the necessary works to protect the pier and safeguard it against future storms.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: Cloonagh pier is owned by Sligo County Council who are responsible for its maintenance and repair.

The position in relation to this pier is that no provision was made for improvement works at Cloonagh under the Fishery Harbour Development Programme 1989-1993. However, a new programme is currently being drawn up for the 1994-1997 period and it is possible that this pier will be considered for improvement works in that context.

Pending finalisation of this programme and clarification of its funding it is difficult for me at this stage to say whether Cloonagh Pier will be included for improvement works under the new Development Plan.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: the reason payments made by a farmer (details supplied) in County Kilkenny to the Land Commission in respect of land annuity have not been acknowledged and receipted; the reason demands are being made on this particular landowner for payments which have already been made; his views on the procedures implemented in this case, particularly in relation to the accountancy procedures adopted; and if he will investigate the matter thoroughly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Land annuities paid by farmers through a bank are receipted by the bank while payments made directly to my Department are receipted only on request.

The land involved was held by the person named under a Temporary Convenience Agreement from 1982 until November 1991, when the allotment was vested. At that time the account relating to the land was changed from a “rent” account to an “annuity” account to fit in with the changed status of the holding. Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Wallace Mr. D. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the main steps being taken to inform relevant Irish manufacturers of the specific potential for developing their business through import substitution; and the procedures in place to monitor progress being made in this regard.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Wallace Mr. D. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the percentage of our annual imports which could be sourced in this country; the ten main such products/commodities; and the annual value of imports in each case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Trade (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Trade (Mr. McCreevy)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 245 and 246 together.

The Government is anxious to encourage Irish firms to maximise the business opportunities available to them in the domestic market. While general import statistics are available from the Central Statistics Office, it is recognised that these alone do not give sufficient detail to enable specific market opportunities to be identified. To help companies identify these opportunities An Bord Tráchtála is currently undertaking the first ever comprehensive sector-by-sector analysis of the competition facing Irish manufacturers in the home market. This new initiative involves the development of unique import statistical databases from which both short and long term opportunities can be identified with particular focus on areas which display high growth rates and reasonably large import values. I recently launched the first report in the series which identified 40 new product opportunities in the food and drink sector. A survey of the building materials sector will be published later this year.

On an ongoing basis, the programmes and services of An Bord Tráchtála's Ireland Division are directed at enhancing the links between Irish sellers and Irish buyers. They provide business sourcing services to large-scale industry, public purchasers and retailing groups together with matching support for potential Irish suppliers. Irish suppliers are informed and invited to participate in An Bord Tráchtála's home market activities through direct mail and press announcements.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Cards.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: if he will increase the income limit for medical card holders to ensure that people with modest income are not denied access to health care; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: if he will grant medical cards to third level students who are suffering as they cannot afford health care; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will automatically grant a medical card to children suffering from severe disablement or ongoing medical conditions which require frequent medication; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 265, 266 and 282 together.

Under the Health Act, 1970 medical cards are issued to persons who, in the opinion of the chief executive officer of the appropriate health board are unable, without undue hardship, to provide general practitioner services for themselves and their dependants.
Income guidelines are available to assist Chief Executive Officers in the determination of a person's eligibility and these are revised annually in line with the Consumer Price Index.

However, these guidelines are not statutorily binding and even though a person's income exceeds the guidelines, that person may still be awarded a medical card if the Chief Executive Officer considers that the person's medical needs or other circumstances would justify this. At present almost 36 per cent of the population hold medical cards.

Persons aged between 16 and 25 years, including students, who are dependants of a person who is not a medical card holder, are not normally entitled to a medical card except where they have an entitlement under EC regulations or where they are in receipt of a Disabled Person's Maintenance Allowance. The decision on whether or not a person is regarded as a dependant or as being financially independent is made by the Chief Executive Officer of the health board on the basis of the circumstances of the individual case. Students who are financially independent are entitled to apply for medical cards and are assessed on the same income criteria as all other applicants.

MainHeading.P: I have given the issues raised by the Deputy very careful consideration and I would of course be anxious that every person who is in genuine need of a medical card should receive one. However, I do not think that it is justifiable to grant an automatic entitlement to a medical card to any particular group without any reference to their means.

It is open to all persons, be they parents of children suffering from severe disablement or ongoing medical conditions requiring frequent medication, persons on modest incomes or third level students to apply to the Chief Executive Officer of the appropriate health board for health services if they are unable to provide these services for themselves and/or their dependants without hardship. I am satisfied that health boards give sympathetic consideration to such applications when the circumstances warrant it.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kilkenny Rape Case.

Qst.Quest: if the report from the South-Eastern Health Board into the failure of the health and social services in regard to the young woman at the centre of the recent Kilkenny rape case will be published; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: As I indicated to the House on the Adjournment on 3 March last, I have directed the South-Eastern Health Board to carry out an immediate investigation of the circumstances of this tragic case, in so far as the health services are concerned. The terms of reference of the investigation team are:

MainHeading.P: —to carry out an investigation, in so far as the health services are concerned, of the circumstances surrounding the abuse referred to in the case heard in the Central Criminal Court on 1 March 1993; in particular to establish why action to halt the abuse was not taken earlier, and
—to make recommendations for the future investigation and management by the health services of cases of suspected child abuse.
The investigation team appointed by the South-Eastern Health Board in response to my direction is headed by Catherine McGuinness, Senior Counsel, who is being assisted by:
—Martin Hynes, Programme Manager for Community Care Services, South-Eastern Health Board,
—Dr. Sheila Ryan, Director of Community Care and Medical Officer of Health, Midland Health Board, and
—Brid Clarke, Head Social Worker, Eastern Health Board.
I expect the investigation team to complete its task within four weeks and to report to me very shortly thereafter.
It is my intention to publish the findings and recommendations of the investigation team subject, of course, to the need to preserve the anonymity of the victim and the other parties concerned.

I am concerned to ensure that every measure possible is taken to prevent a recurrence of what happened in this case. Towards this end, I will be discussing the matter with the Chief Executive Officers of the eight Health Boards when I meet them this week. In particular I will be stressing the necessity to ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place in their areas for the identification, investigation and management of child abuse cases.

In the light of these consultations and the results of the investigation being carried out by the South-Eastern Health Board, I shall be reporting to the Government at an early date with recommendations for the introduction of whatever new measures are necessary to improve existing services and procedures for dealing with child abuse, and for the care and protection of children generally.

Qst.Quest: the origins and purposes of the Senior Certificate Examination; the number of schools where the senior certificate examination is an education option at senior cycle; if her attention has been drawn to the national campaign to retain the programme; and if she will make a statement in relation to her intentions for the future of the programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The Senior Certificate programme is a two-year senior cycle course which has been approved as an option for second-level schools as an alternative to the leaving certificate course.

It was designed primarily as a course of study for transition from school to working life for pupils who do not want to do the traditional leaving certificate and feel suited to a course which is more practical in content.
The course was developed over a period of eight years by Irish teachers and research officers under a European programme on the transition from school to adult life and introduced in 1984.
A school must have the prior approval of my Department to offer the programme. It is in operation in 61 schools at present.
Some schools conducting the programme have indicated a strong desire that the senior certificate option be retained and actively promoted.

As I indicated in my reply to Question No. 556 on 10 February 1993, the future of the senior certificate will be considered in the context of the future structure and content of the senior cycle of second-level education. This matter is discussed in the Green Paper on Education and will be further considered in the light of the views expressed by the various interested parties.

Speaker.P: The following appointments, which have been made since my appointment and that of the Minister of State, are encompassed by the Deputy's question: Mr. Patrick Keating, Education Adviser, member of the Labour Party; Mr. James Wrynn, Partnership Programme Manager, member of the Labour Party; Ms Sinead Bruton, Press Officer, member of the Labour Party; Ms Cliodhna Ferris, Dáil Secretary, member of the Labour Party.

Qst.Quest: if she will have arrangements made to provide school bus transport from Carhan, Caherciveen, County Kerry, to national schools in the town of Caherciveen, County Kerry; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The service from the Carhan area, which operated up to the end of the summer term 1989, cannot be re-established by my Department because of an insufficient number of eligible children offering for transport.
As is normal in such situations, my Department has offered alternative grant-aid towards the cost of private transport arrangements to those children who qualify for such aid. One family qualified.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Facilities for Hearing Impaired Children.

Qst.Quest: if she will sanction the provision of an educational facility in County Kerry for children with impaired hearing at an early date; if this facility will be opened before the end of April 1993; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The question of providing a special class in County Kerry for hearing impaired children is being actively pursued at present by my Department's Inspectorate.
However, it would not be possible at this stage to say whether such a facility can be provided.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Capital Projects for Primary Schools.

Qst.Quest: the number of capital projects for primary schools which she has included in 1993 building programme for primary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: On the basis of the £18.7 million allocated this year for the national schools capital programme I have scheduled 43 major projects to proceed to construction during 1993. This is in addition to the 38 major projects already under construction at the beginning of the year. Upwards of 1,000 minor capital projects will be undertaken also at national schools during 1993 and on past trends 50 or so schools will require to be provided with prefabricated accommodation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rathkeale (Limerick) School.

Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement with regard to the current status of the proposal to build a new second level school in Rathkeale, County Limerick; whether she has made financial provision for this school in 1993; and if not whether she will allow tenders for the contract of the school to be finalised before the end of 1993 so that work on the project can actually begin on the site early in 1994.
if funding has been provided for a post-primary school (details supplied) in County Limerick; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos 313 and 314 together.

MainHeading.P: Architectural planning of the project is proceeding and approval was given to the County Limerick Vocational Education Committee in January 1993, to prepare the stage 4/5 documentation (Detail Design/Contract Documents).

It has not been possible for me to include this project in the 1993 second level capital programme because of other demands deemed to be of a higher priority which had to take precedence. It will continue to be considered for inclusion in the programme in the light of available resources and other commitments and priorities.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if it is proposed to make grant aid available for the provision of proper toilet facilities for Cloonlyon national school, Charlestown, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has approved a grant in respect of the new toilets at this school under its emergency and minor grants scheme. The necessary drawings and specifications are being completed to allow the work to commence within the next two months.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the present pupil/teacher ratio in second level schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The pupil-teacher ratio in second level schools, having regard to total enrolment and the total number of teachers, is approximately 17.4:1.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of additional second level teaching posts created in 1991 and 1992 in accordance with the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The net additional increase in wholetime teacher equivalent posts in the second level area in accordance with the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress is as follows: 1991/92 — 263; 1992/93 — 310.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of second level schools with 500 pupils or more which do not have ex-quota vice-principals.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of additional vice-principal teachers who received recognition on the ex-quota basis in post-primary schools in 1992-93 in schools with 500 pupils or more in accordance with the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 318 and 319 together.

On the basis of enrolments at the end of September, 1991 ninety four second level schools with 500 pupils or more qualified for an ex-quota vice-principal under the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress in the 1992/93 school year.

Enrolments at the end of September, 1992 show that a further 218 schools have enrolments in excess of 500 and these schools will be allocated vice-principal posts on an ex-quota basis over the next two years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of additional whole-time posts of guidance counsellors which have been created in 1992/93 in secondary and community/comprehensive schools in the 350-499 enrolment category.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of secondary and community/comprehensive schools in the 350-499 pupil category which do not have access to specialist ex-quota career counselling.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 320 and 321 together.

An additional 21.5 whole-time teacher equivalents for guidance were allocated to 43 secondary and community/ comprehensive schools in the 350-499 enrolment category under the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress in 1992/93.

Enrolments at 30 September 1992 show that a further 75 schools have enrolments between 350 and 499 and each of these schools will qualify for the allocation of 0.5 of a whole-time post in respect of guidance in the next two years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of schools in the categories 100-199 pupils, 200-299 pupils, 300-399 pupils, 400-499 pupils which have received grants under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress agreement for the provision of caretaking and clerical services in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is as follows. I have also given the number of relevant schools that have enrolments of 500+ pupils, as the programme was introduced on a phased basis beginning, in 1992, with the bigger schools. Additional funds have been made available for 1993 to enable more schools to be provided with these services and it is intended that this process will continue over the next few years.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Scoil Nua i nGaeltacht na Rinne.

Qst.Quest: an bhfuil sé i gceist aici airgead a chur ar fáil do scoil nua dara leibhéal i nGaeltacht na Rinne, mar atá molta ag Coiste Gairmoideachais Chontae Phort Láirge agus an ndéanfaidh sí ráiteas faoin scéal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Maidir leis an scoil nua dara leibhéal atá molta ag Coiste Gairmoideachais Chontae Phort Láirge le haghaidh Scoil San Nioclas i nGaeltacht na Rinne, tá an Roinn i gcomhfhreagras leis an gcoiste faoi láthair i dtaobh láithreán togála oiriunach a fháil don scoil.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: when the opening of the Ashbourne second level school, County Meath, will take place.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: when the building of the Ashbourne second level school, County Meath, will commence.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the amount of money being allocated in 1993 for the second level school in Ashbourne, County Meath.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if a fire safety certificate has now been received by her Department in relation to Ashbourne second level school, County Meath; if the money was made available for expenditure in 1993; if the commitment of her predecessor to start the building in January 1993, given in March 1992, and confirmed in July 1992, will be honoured; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the builder's name was announced by her predecessor in November 1992, and that construction must commence on this 18 month contract in March 1993 in order to ensure that the building is ready to receive its first students in September 1994.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 324, 325, 326 and 329 together.
A commitment was given by my predecessor that this project would commence in January 1993 provided unforeseen circumstances did not disrupt this schedule.

Architectural planning is not completed as circumstances, including the very recent acquisition of a fire certificate, have not allowed the planning to be finalised. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cork School Development Funding.

Qst.Quest: if she will sanction funding in order that St. Angela's Girls Secondary School, Patrick's Hill, Cork, can carry out its development plans.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Proposals for major up-grading work to this school were submitted in 1992. Following examination of the position in my Department and discussion with the school authorities, an amended set of proposals is awaited.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the shortage of post-primary school places in South County Meath where the only community college in Dunshaughlin must refuse pupils for September 1994; if her attention has further been drawn to the fact that, due to the non-allocation of £190,000 to build a school extension required to address the imbalance in the curriculum which has been brought about due to lack of space, the school must refuse vocational education to pupils and insist on academic education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The planning of additional accommodation at this school is currently in progress. It has not been possible to include the proposed extension at this school in the 1993 second level programme because of other demands deemed to be of a higher priority which had to take precedence. The project will continue to be considered for inclusion in the programme in the light of available resources and other commitments and priorities.

MainHeading.RHead: Commission on the Status of Women
MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Second Commission on the Status of Women.

Qst.hpid: Miss M. Wallace Miss M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: the priority she intends giving to the implementation of the recommendations of the Second Commission on the Status of Women in her areas of responsibility; and the process of consultation she intends employing in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am having the proposals in the report of the Second Commission on the Status of Women examined in my Department with a view to identifying short term and long term policy implications.
I intend giving this examination a very high priority in my Department.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a request from the board of management of a school (details supplied) in County Clare to discuss the difficulties being experienced by students and teachers; and, if so, when this meeting will take place.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have received representations on behalf of the board of management of the school in County Clare referred to by the Deputy to meet a deputation to discuss the school's building project.
I have considered this matter and I have decided that no useful purpose would be served by meeting a deputation at this time.

The Deputy will be aware that it was not possible, because of other demands deemed to be of higher priority which had to take precedence, to include this project in the Primary Schools Capital Programme in 1993. It will continue to be sympathetically considered for inclusion in the programme in due course.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if she will meet the national association of training centres for travelling people in order to discuss their situation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There is no record in my Department of a request from the association to meet me. I will be glad to arrange a meeting, in the first instance, between representatives of the association and senior officials of my Department. Such a meeting will be arranged if the association contacts my office.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that registration forms for many schools are phrased in a sexist manner which seeks the father's occupation only; and the action, if any, she intends to take in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The enrolment of pupils in schools is a matter for the management authorities of the individual schools. As my Department is not involved in the enrolment process, I would not be aware of any registration forms used by schools.
I would not condone the use of any forms phrased in a sexist manner if such are in use.
I note the Deputy's concern in the matter, however, and I will arrange to have it brought to the attention of school management representative bodies.

Qst.Quest: if she will provide school transport to Cornagee national school, Dowra, County Leitrim for persons (details supplied); and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department received an application for transport for the children concerned from the chairperson of the Board of Management of Cornagee national school on 11 February 1993. The application was forwarded to Bus Éireann, my Department's agents in such matters, for investigation. My Department hopes to be in a position to reach a decision on the case when Bus Éireann's report is received.
I will inform the Deputy of the outcome.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: the position on the application from Corpus Christi national school, Drumcondra, Dublin 9, which has 412 pupils but no secretary or caretaker; and when these positions will be approved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress a phased programme of financial assistance by way of a supplementary grant for the provision of caretaking and clerical services in national schools has been introduced from 1 September 1992.
The initial phase of the programme targeted primary schools with enrolments of 500 pupils or over which have not had caretaking and/or clerical assistance.
Therefore this school does not satisfy the established criteria under this phase of the programme.
Consideration is now being given to phase two of the programme, but it is not possible at this stage to state when the school in question might be assisted under the programme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Amalgamation of Schools.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement on reports that a study is being carried out by her Department examining the amalgamation of Ballymun senior comprehensive school with the junior schools; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that there is widespread local objection to the idea; the purpose of the study; the alternative plans, if any, which are being considered for the school buildings and grounds should amalgamation proceed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There are three comprehensive schools in Ballymun — Junior Boys, Junior Girls, and a Co-Educational Senior School. These three schools are managed by a single board.

My Department has been in communication with the board regarding the more effective educational use of three school buildings and is currently examining its proposals and recommendations in this regard. In the course of the examination the possible options for alternative use for the buildings and grounds in the event of an amalgamation will be considered.

MainHeading.P: My Department is aware of the concerns of the local community regarding the implications, educational and social, for the Ballymun area, of a re-organisation of the existing three comprehensive schools. Cognisance will be taken of this also in arriving at a decision in the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: her views on ongoing reports of a lack of space in the Library in Dublin City University; and the action, if any being taken to resolve the overcrowding.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The provision of additional library facilities was completed in 1991 at Dublin City University at a cost of £600,000 approximately.

The future library provision in DCU is among the requirements of the third-level sector being considered by my Department in the context of submissions for aid under the next European Regional Development Fund programme commencing in 1994.
